segments.text: This is clearly a field you're desperately concerned about.
Yeah, good old jock.
We've got a problem with him.
I'm not sure that the ocean is really dying per se, but I've been up and down the east coast of the United States quite a bit, and within five, ten miles of the coast, I think that
Since I've been out there, which is the last 10 or 15 years, we see a lot more garbage floating around, plastics in particular, things that never disappear.
But I think as far as pollution effects go, I think we're selling the biota kind of short.
I think they have a tremendous genetic
variability within the population to survive a lot of these insults that we give them.
What we end up doing is, in the worst aspect, well, in the worst aspect you just kill everything, but that usually doesn't happen in a very large area.
It might be a localized effect.
On the periphery of that, then we have
a very strong natural selection force.

We end up picking and choosing, well we don't, but the pollutant which I think once you get it down in concentration a little ways acts as any other environmental stress and what you end up doing is eliminating some species maybe, but we sure as heck select among the rest of the species so that we end up not
really drastically changing the population.

Once you get some undefined distance from the point source of your pollution, the experimental work going on up in Canada, there's a CPEX program that's controlled pollution environmental experiment or something like that.
I forget what the acronym stands for.
And their feeling has been that whenever they perturb the system with a

pollutant, what we end up doing is speeding up the natural succession process that we see in the ocean every year, where we have an environmental stress when you get into high latitudes, you know, when winter comes, knocks things off, and then when it warms up again next year, then things come back again.
And I think the scientists involved up there have gotten to the point where they think of pollution input as just another environmental stress.

And so that the natural population, the ambient population, because they do have in each individual species some reasonable range in the genetic capabilities of it, I don't think we're going to see pollution just killing everything right off.
You might end up, again, in localized areas with some rather peculiar effects.
The work we were doing down in Long Island
was a case in point.
And what had happened down there was there are two major areas in the United States where they raise ducks for commercial purposes.
And the ducks are so darn efficient, all they do is excrete uric acid and sand.
That's about the only thing that comes out the back end of them.
You put grain in the front, and that's what comes out the back.
And there's such heavy concentrations on these little estuaries that it's just like dumping trainloads of fertilizer in there every day.
did in the bay itself was so alter the nutrient chemistry that what they ended up doing was selecting for a certain kind of an organism.
It turned out to be a little green algae that swam around instead of the normal diatoms.
Well, what it did was it wiped out the blue point oyster.
Again, you know, this is, I guess it depends on
what size you want to look at the ocean.
If you're looking at the ocean as a whole, you can sort of shake your head and say, well, what difference does it make?
If you happen to be a blue point oyster connoisseur, well, that's death.
And so it depends on what your point of view is on the sort of thing.
In Great South Bay, what they ended up doing, it turned out to be a very confusing problem.
The boaters
wanted to maintain a couple channels that would be open so they could get their boats in and out, but that's not historically the way the place has been.
A hurricane came along at one point and broke the barrier island, increased the flushing rate of the bay, and sure enough, the oysters started growing again.
Well, the Corps of Engineers said, this can't be, so they filled the inlet in, and of course what happened was that the area was taken over by this little green algae again.
As far as major pollution effects in the ocean, I think what a lot of the people are talking about are such low numbers.
I mean, they have to go out and document it.
They have to measure it some way.
And more often than not, our own analytical capabilities aren't enough to snuff.
And so we're just guessing.
We don't know whether we can demonstrate a pollution effect in most of the ocean.
Again, if you look at where they've been dumping the sludge off New York, sure as heck you can find that effect there.
But again, it's a matter of scale.
My own preference is I would much rather have them dump it out there than in my backyard.
And as long as we are involved with, say, sewage system, garbage collection systems, and things like this,
Probably the ocean's a reasonably good place to put it, mainly because I can't think of a better place.
I'd just as soon not have it, but we've got it.
Another case in point in our department is that I hate like heck to see him go out from the galley three times a day and hurl that stuff over the side of the boat.
This is a very minor thing.
Even if you take all the ships in the world and things like this, we're still talking about a minor input of plastics, aluminum, floating bottles, and things like this.
So we thought, wouldn't it be neat if we got a compactor on the ship and would take out the non-biodegradable materials and would haul them back home again?
And it turns out that the only place we can get rid of this is in Seattle.
If we come into Los Angeles with it, they won't let us offload it.
mainly because the Port of Los Angeles can't handle it.
They've got their own garbage problems out there.
And so I think most people idealistically wouldn't want to put anything into the ocean.
The same thing, they don't want to put it in their backyard.
They want to put it in somebody else's backyard, perhaps.
But the real problem is that we've got a system set up to collect garbage, collect sewage.
And we just can't put a cork in them.
We just can't stop them.
And I think, again, dumping them in the ocean is probably one of the better places to put it right now.
I mean, because we don't have any other place to put it.
If you didn't generate the material, of course, then you're a fat city.
We're having the same problem out where I live.
We're in a rural area, and they put
little school, an elementary school up the road from us.
According to state law, it has to be serviced by a sewer.
And nobody else has sewers out there.
And I'm just opposed to sewers in general, because that's, from sort of a moralistic point of view, I view that as going and throwing my garbage over the fence into my neighbor's yard.
And at least we're in an area now out there where if they control the housing density, they don't have to go to sewers.

Because if they run a sewer in, what's going to happen is they're going to trip the area into a concentrated building, because then they'll be permitted to build five houses per acre, the present time of one house per acre.
But my argument would be, don't run a sewer in there, because then you don't create the population demand that needs a sewer.
I'm not sure which is the chicken and which is the egg, but if we can keep, if you can
generate a system so that you don't generate the problem, then you don't have to solve it.
So I'm not sure.
Again, getting back to the pollution effects or pollution of the ocean as a whole, I think it would be extremely difficult to stop dumping this kind of material.
mainly because we just don't have any other place to put it.
And it's a historical fact.
I mean, New York City is serviced by sewers.
And part of the product of the sewer is sludge.
And I forget what the numbers involved are, but the magnitude of this thing, it just sort of boggles your mind.
You know, we make jokes.
Sure, we'll send it to Louisiana or someplace, you know, Oklahoma, Arizona, you know, as long as it's far enough away from my backyard.
But it's sort of a situation where you can't...
I don't think you can have an ideal solution.
I think you have to make a compromise.
It's trade-offs.
And hopefully this is where...
we can get away from some of this emotionalism that's been associated with the pollution problem so that hopefully the scientific community can give somebody some alternatives.
They might all be bad, but at least you're not stuck with just throwing up your hands and saying nothing can be done.
I think, again, if you trace back the environmental movement,

It seemed to me that most of the people involved were either extremely clever or rather dimwitted, and that they just said, stop it, but never seemed to pay much attention to the fact that you probably couldn't really stop the problem.
The good that has come out of it has probably been
that it's made people in government or in the areas where they make these kinds of decisions to perhaps think about it a little bit.
Because there are, I mean, I am hopeful that there are some alternatives.
I mean, we don't have to keep going the old way over and over again.
We'd like to think that you learn something from history, although sometimes you wonder.
Again, I don't think the ocean is dying, per se.
I think it's, again, it's a matter of scale.
If we talk about the ocean as a whole, I don't think it's dying.
If you look at some localized areas, which a localized area might be 100 square kilometers, yeah, we sure as heck have made some sort of impact.
But if we look at some of the larger natural phenomena,
I'm thinking of things like the El Nino of South America, which is an environmental catastrophe that happens every ten years.
It's not so bad now, but apparently in historical times, thousands and thousands of people would die because either they'd get flooded out or they'd starve to death.
I mean, granted, the birds all died.
We're talking about tens of millions and 20 million birds die in a year because they started that.
Again, the ocean has a fair amount of resiliency.
It can bounce back from these insults.
The other thing that I sort of tried to talk up was that
The oceans themselves are changing over time.
These are natural fluctuations that have to do with whether the North Pole goes to north-south or whether it's in some other orientation, a magnetic North Pole.
We've had large-scale climatic changes that have tremendous impacts, and some of these things have been
Well, I guess the easiest one to demonstrate is a lot of species that were around a million years ago aren't here anymore.
And they've been exterminated.
And whether it was a biological extermination or a climatic extermination, we don't really know.
But just in historical times, we can demonstrate, at least in the fish catch literature from the oceans, that there have been major perturbations
in the oceans over the last five, six hundred years.
The fall of the Hanseatic League on the Baltic is probably a climatic thing.
The herring that they made their living on disappeared, and it's probably a result of climatic changes.
The literature in Japan on the movement of the herring fishery around the islands for the last five, six hundred years show major
fluctuations in the hydrographic characteristics in that region.
So I guess sort of what you boil this thing down to is, what's the natural condition of the ocean?
Is it the one we see now, or the one we want, or the one we're going to get because of natural processes?
And I think there have been some clear
examples of man's impact, i.e., the brown pelican and the DDT story.
But if you look at the small zooplankton or the zooplankton in the North Sea, which has been changing over the last 25 years, it's been documented.
Who knows what's the cause of that?
The unfortunate thing is that there's not enough environmental data to go with this thing.

We don't know what the sea surface temperature is and things like this for the same period of time, but we've had a significant change in this species composition and probably total biomass of the small animals that the fish feed on, and of course we catch the fish.
The irony of the thing is that I think they're catching more fish now than they have 25 years ago, but we're not quite sure what sort of
effect, you know, cause and effect on that sort of thing.
As a matter of fact, I wrote a paper with some other people at an airport once.
We were over in Plymouth, England doing a workshop for UNESCO, or SCORE, I forget which one it was.
about how do you monitor life in the ocean, how do you detect changes.
And so we were sitting down there and we're all reeling off these little cases we know of, of catastrophes happening in the ocean where all fish populations would disappear and things like this.
And like I said, we were sitting there in Heathrow and there was a Swede and a German and there was a Japanese guy and a couple guys from Canada and some from here.
So we're all waiting for planes.

And in a period of half an hour, we decided, well, we'll write this thing up, and we'll send it into a journal, sort of demonstrating that there's probably no steady state equilibrium condition in the ocean, and that probably some of the things that people were attributing to
man's influence was probably just sliding over the top of this natural variation that has happened ever since we've had records.
So there's a certain amount of truth to the old engineering adage that the solution to pollution is dilution.
And again, taking sort of a practical point of view, is that we're probably stuck with this for quite some time.
We're not always happy with it, but I think if you take somewhat a realistic point of view of what's happening in the country and the world, we might be able to do it better.
But at the present time, I don't see us being able, in a realistic sort of a sense, being able to devote the resources that are required to pull off these kinds of problems.
Again, another one which just bugs the living heck out of me is the gasoline stuff, the oil.
To try to knock off the emissions, to try to knock off the lead, what we've done is we've made cars heavier and heavier and heavier.
So we end up using more gas per mile to go from point A to point B.
If you look at the Japanese cars and some of the European cars, per mile travel, they put out a lot less emissions than we do.
I think one of the reasons is they've been paying a buck and a half a gallon for gas for a long time.

Maybe that's the kind of a spur you need to get at that sort of thing, rather than these catalytic converters and all this emission control stuff we have on our cars, which keeps making them heavier and heavier and heavier.
we end up putting out more fumes per mile driven than if we put the economic burr on them to make them lighter and to try to get better mileage.
It's sort of a game you play.
It's like almost any other problem that you face in a laboratory.
You might have to trade off one thing to get another.
And in view of the fact that there must be, I don't know how much oil there is in the whole world, but there must be some finite limit to it.
Maybe it behooves us to try to stretch it out as long as possible.

And I think the environmental, in retrospect, I think this environmental concern is going to be viewed as a pretty heavy cost that we've paid to try to control emissions by going the route that we have done, rather than going the other way of
given it the emphasis to go to lighter vehicles.
So again, it goes back to how do you make decisions on this sort of a thing?
The environmental issue is sure a hot, emotional issue there.
And I think if the government doesn't screw it up,
I think they've put the blanket on it, and you don't hear so much about it now.
A lot of these things have been enacted into legislation, and hopefully they don't just bury it in bureaucracy and government inertia.
But again, I think the scientific community can come up with some reasonable alternatives.
What if?
If you do this, what happens?
If you do that, what happens?
that kind of a game was played on a lot of environmental issues, but hopefully they will in the future.
Is that the direction your work is taking you now?
No, actually, I'm playing fun and games.
No, not quite.
If you go back and look at what I've done professionally, I've sort of
go back and forth and I get sort of problem oriented, sort of mission oriented, and then I get back into sort of the real academic kinds of things.
The major problem I'm working on right now is transport of materials from the surface down through the water column and eventually onto the sea floor.
I got started into this thing primarily
by the question, how do animals on the bottom of the ocean make a living?
From any practical point of view, that's probably kind of a ridiculous problem to be working on.
It turns out it's one of the big unknowns in biological oceanography.
But on the total overall working ecosystem, it probably doesn't make any difference.
But it turned out to be a problem that was rather interesting.
was largely unworked.
So it gives you the satisfaction of working in an area that you can come up with new ideas, new answers at least, or at least data to where none existed before.
So from that point of view, it's very satisfying.
On the outside of our effort, we've got a bunch of chemists playing around.
We provide them with samples and materials.
And these people are involved with hydrocarbon pollution and trace metal pollution and stuff like this.
So we're sort of providing a service to some of the people who are, I guess you would call them environmentally oriented.
I've gotten into the deep ocean mining problem.
Again, basically the tool that we use are some sediment traps.
which we played around with.
We've designed them and developed them here.
And they're probably as good as anybody else's.
And we've been in the game for about two years.

But the thing that got us into the deep ocean mining problem was that you suck up all these nodules and the slurry and everything else, bring it up, sieve out the nodules, and you dump this other stuff back over the side.
What's the environmental impact?
Well, at least in that case, you can actually define some realistic scientific questions that you can actually go out and take some measurements and answer, which isn't usually the way it works.
So in this place, in this particular project, we're providing, again, basically a support service.

We have defined a bunch of actual questions that are ecologically important, and they're also phrased scientifically, so you can go out and take a couple measurements, not a couple, but you can go out and actually measure it, rather than sitting over a couple cans of beer and, you know, there's a lot of rhetoric about it.
I was involved with the SST thing with the ozone layer, and again,

that we were able to structure the questions in such a way that they were, again, of importance to the environmental question, the ecological type thing, are we killing everything, and this sort of thing.
But again, we could frame them into a scientific context so that you could actually do some experiments and measurements, get some data, and actually test them.
Again, this is sort of combining the best of both sides.
I mean, here you have an interesting, again, it's an interesting little scientific problem.
It's got a start, middle, and a finish, you know, when you're done with it.
It also was of interest to the environmental people.
But I don't see that that kind of a program comes very easy.
Either you're lucky and you can fall into it, or it's the right people at the right time at the right place.
But to try to manage something like that I think would be extremely difficult.
I really don't know how you make these things work.
I've been involved with a number of these kinds of efforts in the past, and when I look back at them,
trying to figure out why they worked or why they didn't work.
There are no principles.
There's no such management.
You just can't come up with any management principles on this sort of a thing.
But yeah, I've been involved with, like I said, sometimes kind of academic, sometimes mission-oriented things.
And I'm not sure why I flopped from one to the other.
Well, okay, when I was with the ultraviolet light work, after we did our thing and we sort of came to some conclusions, we had a fair amount of pressure on us to change our mind.
And so I think I sort of shied away from that and then I got into my more academic
approach now that I've been doing for the last couple of years.
The SST ozone stuff I did in 73 and 74 and since then I've been more or less looking at gross food chain dynamics in the ocean again.
The deep ocean mining thing is something that's kind of a small project that
probably a one-shot deal as far as I'm concerned.
My involvement will probably be a one-shot deal this October, and that'll be the end of it.
But again, it was, it's the kind of, it got defined in such a way that I think even the most academic type people probably wouldn't object to being involved in it.
But it's, again, it was the right time, right place, right people type of a situation.

But again, drawing more and more people into the so-called environmentally directed, oriented kind of problems, I guess the biggest thing that always happens is that they find out they can't answer any questions.
They either phrase the question at such a level that no mortal can answer them.
Or if they finally get down to the nitty gritty, they find out there's no database.
And so that you end up trying to solve these things using all sorts of other inputs.
And maybe social economic things are the things that sort of solve these questions anyway.
When Congress gets around to it, I think we're talking about votes and things like that.
And maybe that's the area where they should be solved.
But I think the scientists should be able to hopefully give them some alternatives.
Of course, being here in Seattle and now that the Alaskan pipeline has finally gotten started, we're still writhing over, what are we going to do with the oil once we get it into the boats out there?
Los Angeles says they don't want it.
People around here say we don't want it.

Maybe what they've got to do is build a port somewhere out here, and rather than saying, oh, we've got to be careful, we're not going to have any oil spills, maybe what they ought to say is, look, we're going to have an oil spill, what are we going to do about it?
Rather than trying to prevent the oil spill, maybe they ought to make the assumption, because the probability of an oil spill is one, it's going to happen, and say, okay,
Let's dump some money into it and let's forget about the environmental impact study of worrying about all the little wigglies and crawlies in the bottom.
They're going to die when the oil gets there.
Let's do some engineering studies on it and figure out how we can keep it there rather than letting it slip out of the port and come sloshing down straight to the one that fugues into Puget Sound.
